Award.AwardTitle: Computer simulations of giant fluctuations in mixing fluids
Award.AbstractNarration:
Thermal fluctuations in non-equilibrium systems exhibit remarkable
behavior compared to equilibrium systems. Giant fluctuations in
binary mixtures of miscible fluids have been observed, including
in recent experiments in microgravity. Novel mathematical and
computational challenges need to be addressed in order to include
thermal fluctuations in traditional computational fluid dynamics in
a way that is consistent with statistical mechanics. This proposal
is concerned with the design, mathematical analysis, and computer
implementation of finite-volume methods for fluctuating hydrodynamics
of fluid mixtures, as well as applications to diffusively mixing
fluids in gravity. The following research directions are proposed:
(1) Multi-resolution numerical schemes for solving the compressible
stochastic continuum equations; (2) Algorithms for incompressible,
and (3) low Mach fluctuating hydrodynamics of miscible mixtures on
staggered and collocated grids; (4) Simulations of giant fluctuations
and comparisons to experiments; (5) Study of the contribution
of advection by velocity fluctuations to transport in finite
non-equilibrium systems.

Flows at micro and nano scales typical of new devices and biological
systems are affected by thermal fluctuations. These effects are often
assumed small and are not included in traditional computational
fluid dynamics. However, giant fluctuations in the concentration
of a polymer solution have been observed in recent experiments
conducted in microgravity on a research space shuttle. Computer
simulations are ideally suited for studying the details of this
phenomenon and comparing the predictions of existing theory to
the experimental findings. However, our community still lacks
the appropriate computational tools, including both algorithms and
large-scale parallel codes, to attack this problem. The investigator
and his colleagues will develop such tools and use them to answer
important scientific questions concerning fluctuations in fluids, in
close collaboration with experimentalists. The developed algorithms
will be implemented in a public domain code whose development is funded
through a Software Infrastructure for Sustained Innovation NSF grant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal focused on fluid mechanics in regimes where thermal fluctuations are important, such as flows at micro and nano scales typical of new devices and biological systems, as well as processes where the effect of fluctuations is amplified by strong non-equilibrium effects. Thermal fluctuations in non-equilibrium systems exhibit remarkable behavior compared to equilibrium systems, even in simple steady-state systems in which a constant gradient is imposed externally. Experimental and theoretical studies have observed giant fluctuations in binary mixtures of miscible fluids, especially in recent experiments in microgravity. Computational modeling of these effects was lacking before the start of this project, as was a detailed comparison between the predictions of fluctuating hydrodynamic theory and experimental measurements.

As part of the work supported by this project, the PI and collaborators have: (1) Developed algorithms for integrating Langevin stochastic differential equations, which appear in a variety of contexts in statistical physics, computational chemistry and material modeling. (2) Developed novel finite-volume algorithms that include thermal fluctuations in traditional computational fluid dynamics in a way that is consistent with statistical mechanics. (3) Implemented these algorithms in the public-domain software framework IBAMR. (3) Applied these algorithms to discover new physics and provide new insights on diffusion in liquid mixtures. (4) Collaborated with experimental groups in Europe to compare the predictions of computational fluctuating hydrodynamics to experimental measurements of giant fluctuations in binary mixtures.

The newly-developed methods and scientific discoveries resulting from this work have been disseminated to the community in a number of different ways. Firstly, the algorithms developed in this work have been implemented in the open-source software framework IBAMR, thus making them accessible to other researchers. Secondly, around a dozen scientific publications have already been published or are in the process of being reviewed in applied mathematics and physics journals. Lastly, the PI has attended several national and international workshops and conferences and given invited presentations describing the work supported by this project.

The PI developed and taught (Fall 2011 and 2013) a special-topics graduate course in the field of coarse-grained computational and mathematical modeling of materials. This course has now become a standard offering in the Advanced Topics graduate courses at the Courant Institute. Two postdocs and three graduate students were supported in part by this project and mentored by the PI. Both students and postdoces were trained in the fields of statistical mechanics, fluid mechanics, stochastic methods, numerical analysis, and high-performance computing. They also used and contributed to the development of state-of-the-art scientific software, in collaboration with Boyce Griffith (IBAMR software framework) and the group of John Bell at Lawrence Berkeley Labs (BoxLib software framework).
